questions.text: A 46-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her wife 1 hour after the onset of chest palpitations. Her symptoms began suddenly while she was having some beers with friends and have persisted since then. She has not had shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness, or loss of consciousness. She has experienced these palpitations before, but they typically resolve spontaneously within a few minutes. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 180/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. An ECG is shown. Repeated, forceful exhalation against a closed glottis while supine fails to relieve her symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

If vagal maneuvers do not terminate AVNRT, IV adenosine administration is the next step in management. Adenosine has a rapid onset of action and successfully terminates AVNRT in over 80% of cases. During IV administration, patients should be in the supine position and undergo continuous blood pressure and electrocardiographic monitoring. Adenosine slows down conduction in the AV node, resulting in short-term heart block, which can create an uncomfortable sensation that patients should be made aware of beforehand. Adverse effects include facial flushing and shortness of breath, hypotension, and bradycardia. Patients with asthma and reactive airway disease should not be given adenosine because of the risk of bronchospasm.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous verapamil (a calcium channel blocker) can terminate AVNRT, but it is generally considered a second-line agent. Adverse effects include hypotension and bradycardia. Verapamil can also be used in atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, and multifocal atrial tachycardia.

C) INCORRECT:

Electrical cardioversion is the management option of choice in patients with supraventricular tachycardia who have signs of hemodynamic instability (e.g., hypotension, shortness of breath, chest pain, shock, altered mental status). This patient is hemodynamically stable, and thus an alternative management strategy is preferred.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous digoxin (a cardiac glycoside) can terminate AVNRT, but it is generally considered a second-line agent, particularly because digoxin has a low therapeutic index; toxicity can cause cardiac arrhythmias, gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain), neurologic symptoms (e.g. confusion, weakness, lethargy), and visual changes. Digoxin can also be used in atrial fibrillation.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous beta blockers (e.g., metoprolol, esmolol) can terminate AVNRT, but they are generally considered second-line agents. Patients with severe asthma and reactive airway disease should not receive beta blockers because of their risk of inducing bronchospasm. Other adverse effects include hypotension and bradycardia.

F) INCORRECT:

Intravenous diltiazem (a calcium channel blocker) can terminate AVNRT, but it is generally considered a second-line agent. Adverse effects include hypotension and bradycardia. Diltiazem is also used for atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter.

G) INCORRECT:

Catheter ablation of the aberrant pathway (in this case, within the AV node) is highly effective and generally the preferred long-term management strategy for recurrent symptomatic AVNRT. There is a small risk of resultant AV node block and need for a cardiac pacemaker. It should be considered as an option in the chronic management of this patient. However, she currently requires immediate management of her arrhythmia.
questions.hint: ECG showing regular narrow QRS complexes with no clear P waves (the P waves are hidden within the QRS complexes) suggests atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT), a supraventricular tachycardia caused by a reentry circuit in the AV node. Stress, alcohol, and caffeine can trigger episodes of AVNRT. Vagal maneuvers have failed to terminate the arrhythmia in this patient.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of recurrent episodes of chest pain, racing pulse, dizziness, and difficulty breathing. The episodes last up to several minutes. She also reports urinary urgency and two episodes of loss of consciousness followed by spontaneous recovery. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Holter monitoring is performed. ECG recordings during episodes of tachycardia show a QRS duration of 100 ms, regular RR-interval, and absent P waves. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Macroreentrant rhythm in the right atrium through cavotricuspid isthmus
AV node with slow and fast pathway
Fibrosis of the sinoatrial node and surrounding myocardium
Mutations in genes that code for myocyte ion channels
Bursts of electrical activity from automatic foci near the pulmonary veins

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A macroreentrant rhythm in the right atrium is one underlying mechanism of atrial flutter. While atrial flutter may manifest with symptoms of cardiac arrhythmia such as palpitations or syncope, it is most commonly asymptomatic and is classically characterized on ECG by the sawtooth appearance of P waves (“flutter waves”).
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Atrial rate ∼ 240/min, ventricular rate ∼ 60/min (4:1 AV conduction ratio)
– Left axis deviation: R > S in I (green complex); S > R in aVF (red complex)
– P waves with a “sawtooth” appearance (flutter waves)
– Regular, narrow QRS complexes
– Prolonged PR interval (∼ 280 ms)
– Horizontal ST depression (0.1–0.2 mV) with T-wave inversion in leads I and V2–V6, suggestive of myocardial ischemia

These findings indicate atrial flutter with 4:1 conduction, probably secondary to the observed myocardial ischemia.

B) CORRECT:

Alternative electrical conduction pathways (one fast and one slow) in the atrioventricular node (AV node) are the underlying cause of AVNRT. The presence of an extra, fast accessory pathway occasionally leads to a nonextinguishable circulating electrical impulse (reentrant circuit) within the AV node that activates the atria and ventricles simultaneously and at a rapid rate. This produces episodic symptoms of palpitations, dyspnea, chest pain, dizziness and/or syncope.
Image Description:

AVNRT is a tachyarrhythmia caused by a dysfunctional AV node with two electrical pathways, one fast with a long refractory period and one slow with a short refractory period (dual AV nodal physiology). During normal sinus rhythm, the conduction occurs via the fast pathway, and the incoming current from the slow pathway is extinguished (top right image).

Typical AVNRT is triggered by an atrial premature beat (APB).

(1) An APB arrives at the AV node during the fast pathway's refractory period. The impulse is, therefore, conducted through the slow pathway, which is out of its refractory period.
(2) When the impulse reaches the distal junction of the two pathways, the fast pathway has recovered its excitability and the impulse can travel up retrograde.
(3) The impulse reaches the atria, leading to an almost simultaneous depolarization of the atria and ventricles. The current reenters the slow pathway.
(4) A reentry circuit is created with anterograde conduction across the slow-conducting pathway and retrograde conduction in the fast pathway resulting in sustained tachycardia.

C) INCORRECT:

Preexcitation of the ventricles via a congenital accessory conduction pathway between the atria and ventricles is the underlying mechanism of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). Although WPW can result in PSVT, it would exhibit a shortened PR interval and a delta wave in the QRS complex on ECG. In addition, WPW is a less common cause of PSVT than AVNRT.
Image Description:

Conduction pathways and characteristic ECG findings in normal impulse transmission and in WPW syndrome. Note that the condition is referred to as WPW syndrome only if the characteristic ECG findings are present and the patient is also symptomatic or there is evidence of arrhythmia; if the characteristic ECG findings are present without these additional features, the condition is referred to as “WPW pattern.”

Left (normal impulse transmission and normal ECG findings): PR interval 120–200 ms; QRS duration < 100 ms

Right (WPW impulse transmission and characteristic ECG findings): short PR interval < 120 ms; slurred upstroke (delta wave) at the start of the QRS complex with widened QRS ≥ 120 ms

D) INCORRECT:

Fibrosis of the sinoatrial node and surrounding myocardium is the underlying mechanism of sick sinus syndrome (SSS). While symptoms of SSS can include dizziness and syncope, this is usually secondary to sinus node dysfunction causing persistent sinus bradycardia (more commonly than a supraventricular tachycardia) and is classically seen in elderly patients. It is less likely that this patient has SSS than an AVNRT, which is not related to fibrosis of the SA node.

E) INCORRECT:

Genetic mutations affecting myocyte ion channels are the underlying mechanism of congenital long QT syndrome (LQTS). Although LQTS can manifest with palpitations, dizziness, and syncope, this patient's history of such episodes is limited to the past 6 months, and she has no family history of sudden cardiac death or associated congenital hearing loss to suggest genetic LQTS syndrome. AVNRT is not caused by genetic mutations in the loci of myocyte ion channels.

F) INCORRECT:

The firing of multiple foci in the atria (near the pulmonary veins) is usually the underlying mechanism of atrial fibrillation (Afib). Afib can also cause episodes of palpitations, dyspnea, chest pain, dizziness and/or syncope. However, the ECG of Afib would have an irregular RR interval and erratic spikes (also known as course fibrillatory waves) on the baseline in the place of P waves.
Image Description:

6-lead ECG (paper speed 25 mm/s)

– Heart rate: ~135/min
– Irregularly irregular RR intervals (examples indicated by black overlay)
– Normal axis
– Absent P waves
– Coarse fibrillatory waves (f waves; examples indicated by red overlay) can be seen between the QRS complexes. These are characterized by low amplitude, high frequency, and irregular morphology, and should not be confused with P waves or flutter waves.

The absence of P waves with irregularly irregular RR intervals and an elevated heart rate indicates atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms together with her ECG findings (narrow QRS complex with no discernible P waves) suggest paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), which is most commonly caused by atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of an episode of syncope 2 hours ago. He reports sudden onset of palpitations followed by loss of consciousness while carrying his groceries to his car. He is unable to recall any further details and does not have any chest pain or dizziness. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, gastroparesis, and osteoarthritis of the knees. Medications include lisinopril, metformin, and ondansetron as needed for nausea. He also takes methadone daily for chronic pain. Apart from an abrasion on his forehead, he appears well. His temperature is 37.2 °C (98.9 F), pulse is 104/min and regular, and blood pressure is 135/70 mm Hg. While he is in the emergency department, he loses consciousness again. Telemetry shows polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with cyclic alteration of the QRS axis that spontaneously resolves after 30 seconds. Results of a complete blood count, serum electrolyte concentrations, and serum thyroid studies show no abnormalities. Cardiac enzymes are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's syncope?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A prolonged QT interval may be congenital or acquired, and typically remains asymptomatic until patients present with syncope or life-threatening arrhythmias such as TdP. Acquired prolongation of the QT interval can be caused by certain medications (e.g., amiodarone, methadone, ondansetron) or electrolyte imbalances (e.g., hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalcemia). This patient's history of ondansetron and methadone therapy makes drug-induced QT prolongation that progressed to TdP the most likely cause of his syncope. Treatment consists of administering magnesium sulfate regardless of baseline magnesium levels.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

- Regular ectopic atrial rhythm: negative P-waves in II and aVF (normally positive), positive P-waves in aVR (normally negative) and V1 (normally biphasic) (examples indicated by blue overlay)
- Heart rate of approx. 75/min
- Normal cardiac axis
- Normal PR interval (approx. 120 ms), normal QRS duration (approx. 80 ms)
- Prolonged QT interval (QTc approx. 580 ms, example indicated by red overlay)
- Ventricular extrasystoles seen in leads I to III

B) INCORRECT:

Acute myocardial ischemia can manifest with syncope and, in some cases, ventricular tachyarrhythmia, which is seen in this patient with risk factors for coronary artery disease (diabetes mellitus and hypertension). However, he lacks other typical features of acute myocardial ischemia, such as chest pain, lasting ECG changes (e.g., ST changes), and elevated cardiac enzymes.

C) INCORRECT:

A shortened PR interval can be seen in preexcitation syndromes such as Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) and Lown-Ganong-Levine (LGL) syndrome. While these conditions can also manifest with syncope, this patient lacks the characteristic findings of WPW syndrome (i.e., short PR interval, slurring and slow rise of the initial upstroke of the QRS complex, and widened QRS complex) or LGL syndrome (i.e., short PR interval with normal QRS complexes). Instead, TdP is seen, which is not a feature of these conditions. Both WPW and LGL syndrome cause atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia but not ventricular tachycardias like TdP.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)

– Regular sinus rhythm
– Rate 68/min
– Normal axis (R > S in leads I and aVF)
– Short PR interval (112 ms)
– Wide QRS complexes (126 ms) with delta waves (the slurred initial portion of the QRS complex; zoom box)

A short PR interval and widened QRS complexes with delta waves are the characteristic ECG findings of Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome. If seen in asymptomatic patients with no evidence of arrhythmia, this constellation of findings is referred to as the "WPW pattern”.

D) INCORRECT:

A fast accessory conduction pathway can be seen in Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, which can manifest with palpitation and syncope. However, typical ECG findings include a shortened PR interval (< 120 ms), slurring and slow rise of the initial upstroke of the QRS complex (delta wave), and a widened QRS complex. WPW syndrome causes atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia but not ventricular tachycardias such as TdP.
Image Description:

Conduction pathways and characteristic ECG findings in normal impulse transmission and in WPW syndrome. Note that the condition is referred to as WPW syndrome only if the characteristic ECG findings are present and the patient is also symptomatic or there is evidence of arrhythmia; if the characteristic ECG findings are present without these additional features, the condition is referred to as “WPW pattern.”

Left (normal impulse transmission and normal ECG findings): PR interval 120–200 ms; QRS duration < 100 ms

Right (WPW impulse transmission and characteristic ECG findings): short PR interval < 120 ms; slurred upstroke (delta wave) at the start of the QRS complex with widened QRS ≥ 120 ms

E) INCORRECT:

Prinzmetal angina can lead to ventricular arrhythmias that can manifest with syncope and reversible ECG changes. However, this condition typically manifests with recurrent episodes of retrosternal chest pain or pressure radiating to the neck, jaw, left shoulder, or arm.

F) INCORRECT:

Brugada syndrome can manifest with syncope and ventricular tachyarrhythmia. However, characteristic ECG findings include incomplete right bundle branch block and ST-segment elevations in the anterior precordial leads.
Image Description:

12-lead ECG (paper speed: 50 mm/s)

– Regular sinus rhythm
– Heart rate: ∼83/min
– Right axis deviation: R < S in I, R > S in aVF
– ST elevation ≥ 2 mm and a negative T wave in V1 and V2 (red overlay). The shape of ST elevation seen in V1 is described as “coved.”
– Pseudo-RBBB: The ST changes create a pattern resembling RBBB in V1.

Pseudo-RBBB with ST elevation in V1–V3 is characteristic of Brugada pattern. To diagnose Brugada syndrome, the corresponding clinical criteria must also be met, e.g., VF, syncope, or pertinent family history.

G) INCORRECT:

Hypomagnesemia is a predisposing factor for TdP. However, this patient has no risk factors for hypomagnesemia (e.g., diarrhea, alcoholism, use of diuretics) and lacks other typical features of hypomagnesemia such as neuromuscular manifestations (e.g., tetany, seizures).
questions.hint: Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with cyclic alteration of the QRS axis (sinusoidal waveform) is referred to as torsades de pointes (TdP) and can progress to life-threatening ventricular fibrillation.

questions.text:
A 77-year-old man presents to clinic with his daughter for routine follow-up. He has no complaints, but his daughter notes that he has recently become more fatigued with exertion and is sleeping more frequently. He completed a 10-day course of ciprofloxacin last week for a prostate infection, and his urinary symptoms have completely resolved.
He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and moderate vascular dementia. His current medications include donepezil 10 mg daily, verapamil 180 mg daily, lisinopril 10 mg daily, sotalol 120 mg twice daily, and apixaban 5 mg twice daily.
On physical examination, his temperature is 37.2°C, his blood pressure is 130/60 mm Hg, his heart rate is 45 beats per minute, and his respiratory rate is 12 breaths per minute. His lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination reveals a regular rhythm with no murmurs. Jugular venous pressure is normal. Mild pitting edema is evident in both of his lower extremities.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Reduce the donepezil dose with close follow-up
Stop the verapamil with close follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has mild lower-extremity edema, there is no evidence of intravascular volume overload. An echocardiogram would not be appropriate until after his bradycardia is evaluated.

B) INCORRECT:

Donepezil has been reported to cause bradycardia, and reducing the dose could potentially help this patient. However, an ECG would be indicated first to assess for QTc prolongation.

C) INCORRECT:

Verapamil, a nondihydropyridine calcium-channel blocker, causes negative inotropy and may result in bradycardia. However, simply stopping the medication, which this patient is presumably taking for his atrial fibrillation, would not be appropriate without further evaluation.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s fatigue is likely a consequence of his bradycardia, which is potentially related to the medications he is taking. Polypharmacy is a potential risk given his vascular dementia and advanced age, and three of his medications — donepezil, sotalol, and verapamil — have been associated with bradycardia.

Obtaining an electrocardiogram (ECG) in this case is critical, as the underlying rhythm must be evaluated for any level of atrioventricular (AV) block. In addition, sotalol and ciprofloxacin can cause prolongation of the corrected QT interval (QTc), which, in the setting of significant bradycardia, can compound the risk for torsades de pointes. If the patient is found to have a high level of AV block or significant QTc prolongation, he may require hospitalization or further evaluation with a long-term monitor or electrophysiological study.

Key learning point: When an older adult who takes an antiarrhythmic medication or an atrioventricular nodal blocker develops hemodynamically stable bradycardia, the first step in evaluation is electrocardiography.

E) INCORRECT:

In a patient with confirmed bradycardia, a Holter monitor would not provide any additional diagnostic information that could not be obtained with a simple ECG.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old woman presents to discuss the findings of an electrocardiogram (ECG) that was performed at a pre-participation physical examination she had before joining the soccer team at her school. She reports that her father died of unknown causes at age 48, prompting the ECG. She has a copy of the ECG with her (figure) and is concerned about it. She feels well overall and reports no chest pain, dyspnea, lightheadedness, or palpitations. Her medical history includes polycystic ovary syndrome, hypothyroidism, obesity, and depression. Her medications are levothyroxine 100 μg daily, sertraline 50 mg daily, and a combined oral contraceptive pill.
On physical examination, she has normal vital signs, including a blood pressure of 122/80 mm Hg and a heart rate of 75 beats per minute. Cardiac auscultation reveals normal heart sounds without murmurs. The rest of the physical examination is normal.
Laboratory testing shows a normal complete blood count, a normal basic metabolic panel, a thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 1.5 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.7), and a free thyroxine level of 1.5 ng/dL (0.8–1.8).
What is the most appropriate next step in response to this patient’s electrocardiogram findings?

choices.text: Increase the dose of the levothyroxine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An echocardiogram is generally beneficial in the workup of SVT and other cardiac arrhythmias, to evaluate for potential etiologies such as valvular or structural heart disease. This patient, who has a normal sinus variant and no evidence of a pathologic arrhythmia, does not have any indication for additional imaging.

B) INCORRECT:

A 48-hour continuous ambulatory electrocardiographic monitor would be useful in a patient with cardiac symptoms occurring daily or near-daily, but it is not needed in this patient who is asymptomatic and has a resting ECG showing a benign normal variant.

C) INCORRECT:

A variable R-R interval can be caused by a number of conditions (atrial fibrillation or flutter, atrial tachycardia, premature atrial contractions, and premature ventricular contractions), many of which are managed, at least in part, with a beta-blocker. However, patients with these conditions would have characteristic changes on their ECGs, such as absent or abnormal P-wave morphology, which is not the case for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has a normal thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level; thus, the dose of levothyroxine seems appropriate, and no dose adjustment is indicated. Overreplacement with levothyroxine or other causes of thyrotoxicosis (which would cause a low TSH level) can lead to supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and other atrial arrhythmias, most commonly atrial fibrillation. In contrast, under-replacement with levothyroxine or untreated hypothyroidism (which would be associated with an elevated TSH level) can cause bradyarrhythmias.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s electrocardiogram (ECG) shows sinus rhythm with sinus arrhythmia, which is characterized by variations in the R-R interval (and thus the heart rate) with respiration (faster heart rate with inspiration and slower heart rate with expiration) and by normal, stable P-wave morphology. Sinus arrhythmia is due to variations in autonomic function with respiration. It is a benign, common finding in young, healthy patients and requires no intervention.

Key learning point: Benign sinus arrhythmia is a normal occurrence that does not require further treatment.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after the onset of chest palpitations that began suddenly while she was having some beers. She has not had shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness, or loss of consciousness. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Pulse rate is 180/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Electrocardiography is shown. Vagal maneuvers fail to relieve her symptoms. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

If vagal maneuvers do not terminate AVNRT, IV adenosine administration is the next step in management. Adenosine has a rapid onset of action and successfully terminates AVNRT in over 80% of cases. During IV administration, patients should be in the supine position and undergo continuous blood pressure and electrocardiographic monitoring. Adenosine slows down conduction in the AV node, resulting in short-term heart block, which can create an uncomfortable sensation that patients should be made aware of beforehand. Adverse effects include facial flushing and shortness of breath, hypotension, and bradycardia. Patients with asthma and reactive airway disease should not be given adenosine because of the risk of bronchospasm.

Key learning point: For stable supraventricular tachycardia unresponsive to vagal maneuvers, intravenous adenosine is the first-line acute therapy to terminate the arrhythmia.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous verapamil (a calcium channel blocker) can terminate AVNRT, but it is generally considered a second-line agent. Adverse effects include hypotension and bradycardia. Verapamil can also be used in atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, and multifocal atrial tachycardia.

C) INCORRECT:

Electrical cardioversion is the management option of choice in patients with supraventricular tachycardia who have signs of hemodynamic instability (e.g., hypotension, shortness of breath, chest pain, shock, altered mental status). This patient is hemodynamically stable, and thus an alternative management strategy is preferred.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous beta blockers (e.g., metoprolol, esmolol) can terminate AVNRT, but they are generally considered second-line agents. Patients with severe asthma and reactive airway disease should not receive beta blockers because of their risk of inducing bronchospasm. Other adverse effects include hypotension and bradycardia.

E) INCORRECT:

Catheter ablation of the aberrant pathway (in this case, within the AV node) is highly effective and generally the preferred long-term management strategy for recurrent symptomatic AVNRT. There is a small risk of resultant AV node block and need for a cardiac pacemaker. It should be considered as an option in the chronic management of this patient. However, she currently requires immediate management of her arrhythmia.
questions.hint: ECG showing regular narrow QRS complexes with no clear P waves (the P waves are hidden within the QRS complexes) suggests atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT), a supraventricular tachycardia caused by a reentry circuit in the AV node. Stress, alcohol, and caffeine can trigger episodes of AVNRT. Vagal maneuvers (e.g., repeated, forceful exhalation against a closed glottis while supine) have failed to terminate the arrhythmia in this patient.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 6-month history of recurrent episodes of palpitations, dizziness, and difficulty breathing. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Electrocardiography recordings during episodes of tachycardia show narrow QRS complexes, regular RR-intervals, and no discernible P waves. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Macroreentrant rhythm in the right atrium through the cavotricuspid isthmus
Two conduction pathways (one fast and one slow) within the atrioventricular node
Accessory conduction pathway bypassing the atrioventricular node
Fibrosis of the sinoatrial node and surrounding myocardium
Bursts of electrical activity from automatic foci near the pulmonary veins

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A macroreentrant rhythm in the right atrium is one underlying mechanism of atrial flutter. While atrial flutter may manifest with symptoms of cardiac arrhythmia such as palpitations or syncope, it is most commonly asymptomatic and is classically characterized on ECG by the sawtooth appearance of P waves (“flutter waves”).

B) CORRECT:

Alternative electrical conduction pathways (one fast and one slow) in the atrioventricular node (AV node) are the underlying cause of AVNRT. The presence of an extra, fast accessory pathway occasionally leads to a nonextinguishable circulating electrical impulse (reentrant circuit) within the AV node that activates the atria and ventricles simultaneously and at a rapid rate. This produces episodic symptoms of palpitations, dyspnea, chest pain, dizziness and/or syncope.
Image Description:

AVNRT is a tachyarrhythmia caused by a dysfunctional AV node with two electrical pathways, one fast with a long refractory period and one slow with a short refractory period (dual AV nodal physiology). During normal sinus rhythm, the conduction occurs via the fast pathway, and the incoming current from the slow pathway is extinguished (top right image).

Typical AVNRT is triggered by an atrial premature beat (APB).

(1) An APB arrives at the AV node during the fast pathway's refractory period. The impulse is, therefore, conducted through the slow pathway, which is out of its refractory period.
(2) When the impulse reaches the distal junction of the two pathways, the fast pathway has recovered its excitability and the impulse can travel up retrograde.
(3) The impulse reaches the atria, leading to an almost simultaneous depolarization of the atria and ventricles. The current reenters the slow pathway.
(4) A reentry circuit is created with anterograde conduction across the slow-conducting pathway and retrograde conduction in the fast pathway resulting in sustained tachycardia.

C) INCORRECT:

Preexcitation of the ventricles via a congenital accessory conduction pathway between the atria and ventricles is the underlying mechanism of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). Although WPW can result in PSVT, it would exhibit a shortened PR interval and a delta wave in the QRS complex on ECG. In addition, WPW is a less common cause of PSVT than AVNRT.

D) INCORRECT:

Fibrosis of the sinoatrial node and surrounding myocardium is the underlying mechanism of sick sinus syndrome (SSS). While symptoms of SSS can include dizziness and syncope, this is usually secondary to sinus node dysfunction causing persistent sinus bradycardia (more commonly than a supraventricular tachycardia) and is classically seen in elderly patients. It is less likely that this patient has SSS than an AVNRT, which is not related to fibrosis of the SA node.

E) INCORRECT:

The firing of multiple foci in the atria (near the pulmonary veins) is usually the underlying mechanism of atrial fibrillation (Afib). Afib can also cause episodes of palpitations, dyspnea, and dizziness. However, the ECG of Afib would have an irregular RR interval and erratic spikes (also known as course fibrillatory waves) on the baseline in the place of P waves.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms together with her ECG findings (narrow QRS complex with no discernible P waves) suggest paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), which is most commonly caused by atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT).

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to discuss the findings of an electrocardiography (ECG) that was performed at a pre-participation physical examination she had before joining the soccer team at her school. A copy of the ECG is shown and the patient is concerned about it. She feels well overall and reports no chest pain, dyspnea, lightheadedness, or palpitations. She has hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine 100 μg daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac auscultation reveals normal heart sounds without murmurs. Laboratory testing shows a normal complete blood count; thyroid-stimulating hormone and free thyroxine levels are within normal limits. What is the most appropriate next step in response to this patient’s electrocardiography findings?

choices.text: Increase the dose of the levothyroxine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An echocardiography is generally beneficial in the workup of SVT and other cardiac arrhythmias, to evaluate for potential etiologies such as valvular or structural heart disease. This patient, who has a normal sinus variant and no evidence of a pathologic arrhythmia, does not have any indication for additional imaging.

B) INCORRECT:

A 48-hour continuous ambulatory electrocardiographic monitor would be useful in a patient with cardiac symptoms occurring daily or near-daily, but it is not needed in this patient who is asymptomatic and has a resting ECG showing a benign normal variant.

C) INCORRECT:

A variable R-R interval can be caused by a number of conditions (atrial fibrillation or flutter, atrial tachycardia, premature atrial contractions, and premature ventricular contractions), many of which are managed, at least in part, with a beta-blocker. However, patients with these conditions would have characteristic changes on their ECGs, such as absent or abnormal P-wave morphology, which is not the case for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has a normal thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level; thus, the dose of levothyroxine seems appropriate, and no dose adjustment is indicated. Overreplacement with levothyroxine or other causes of thyrotoxicosis (which would cause a low TSH level) can lead to supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and other atrial arrhythmias, most commonly atrial fibrillation. In contrast, under-replacement with levothyroxine or untreated hypothyroidism (which would be associated with an elevated TSH level) can cause bradyarrhythmias.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s electrocardiography (ECG) shows sinus rhythm with sinus arrhythmia, which is characterized by variations in the R-R interval (and thus the heart rate) with respiration (faster heart rate with inspiration and slower heart rate with expiration) and by normal, stable P-wave morphology. Sinus arrhythmia is due to variations in autonomic function with respiration. It is a benign, common finding in young, healthy patients and requires no intervention.

Key learning point: Benign sinus arrhythmia is a normal occurrence that does not require further treatment.

questions.text: You are seeing a 46-year-old woman who is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after sudden onset of chest palpitations that began while she was drinking beer. She has not experienced shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness, or loss of consciousness. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. Her pulse is 180/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg. Physical examination is normal. Electrocardiography is provided. Vagal maneuvers have not relieved her symptoms. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous beta blockers (e.g., metoprolol, esmolol) can terminate AVNRT, but they are generally considered second-line agents. Patients with severe asthma and reactive airway disease should not receive beta blockers because of their risk of inducing bronchospasm. Other adverse effects include hypotension and bradycardia.

B) INCORRECT:

Catheter ablation of the aberrant pathway (in this case, within the AV node) is highly effective and generally the preferred long-term management strategy for recurrent symptomatic AVNRT. There is a small risk of resultant AV node block and need for a cardiac pacemaker. It should be considered as an option in the chronic management of this patient. However, she currently requires immediate management of her arrhythmia.

C) INCORRECT:

Intravenous verapamil (a calcium channel blocker) can terminate AVNRT, but it is generally considered a second-line agent. Adverse effects include hypotension and bradycardia. Verapamil can also be used in atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, and multifocal atrial tachycardia.

D) INCORRECT:

Electrical cardioversion is the management option of choice in patients with supraventricular tachycardia who have signs of hemodynamic instability (e.g., hypotension, shortness of breath, chest pain, shock, altered mental status). This patient is hemodynamically stable, and thus an alternative management strategy is preferred.

E) CORRECT:

If vagal maneuvers do not terminate AVNRT, IV adenosine administration is the next step in management. Adenosine has a rapid onset of action and successfully terminates AVNRT in over 80% of cases. During IV administration, patients should be in the supine position and undergo continuous blood pressure and electrocardiographic monitoring. Adenosine slows down conduction in the AV node, resulting in short-term heart block, which can create an uncomfortable sensation that patients should be made aware of beforehand. Adverse effects include facial flushing and shortness of breath, hypotension, and bradycardia. Patients with asthma and reactive airway disease should not be given adenosine because of the risk of bronchospasm.

Key learning point: If vagal maneuvers fail to terminate stable supraventricular tachycardia, intravenous adenosine is the first-line acute pharmacologic therapy.
questions.hint: ECG showing regular narrow QRS complexes with no clear P waves (the P waves are hidden within the QRS complexes) suggests atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT), a supraventricular tachycardia caused by a reentry circuit in the AV node. Stress, alcohol, and caffeine can trigger episodes of AVNRT. Vagal maneuvers (e.g., repeated, forceful exhalation against a closed glottis while supine) have failed to terminate the arrhythmia in this patient.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of recurrent episodes of palpitations, dizziness, and shortness of breath. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Electrocardiography recordings during episodes of tachycardia show narrow QRS complexes, regular RR intervals, and no discernible P waves. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of her condition?

choices.text: Macroreentrant rhythm in the right atrium through the cavotricuspid isthmus.
Fibrosis of the sinoatrial node and surrounding myocardium.
Accessory conduction pathway bypassing the atrioventricular node.
Bursts of electrical activity from automatic foci near the pulmonary veins.
Two conduction pathways (one fast and one slow) within the atrioventricular node.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A macroreentrant rhythm in the right atrium is one underlying mechanism of atrial flutter. While atrial flutter may manifest with symptoms of cardiac arrhythmia such as palpitations or syncope, it is most commonly asymptomatic and is classically characterized on ECG by the sawtooth appearance of P waves (“flutter waves”).

B) INCORRECT:

Fibrosis of the sinoatrial node and surrounding myocardium is the underlying mechanism of sick sinus syndrome (SSS). While symptoms of SSS can include dizziness and syncope, this is usually secondary to sinus node dysfunction causing persistent sinus bradycardia (more commonly than a supraventricular tachycardia) and is classically seen in elderly patients. It is less likely that this patient has SSS than an AVNRT, which is not related to fibrosis of the SA node.

C) INCORRECT:

Preexcitation of the ventricles via a congenital accessory conduction pathway between the atria and ventricles is the underlying mechanism of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). Although WPW can result in PSVT, it would exhibit a shortened PR interval and a delta wave in the QRS complex on ECG. In addition, WPW is a less common cause of PSVT than AVNRT.

D) INCORRECT:

The firing of multiple foci in the atria (near the pulmonary veins) is usually the underlying mechanism of atrial fibrillation (Afib). Afib can also cause episodes of palpitations, dyspnea, and dizziness. However, the ECG of Afib would have an irregular RR interval and erratic spikes (also known as course fibrillatory waves) on the baseline in the place of P waves.

E) CORRECT:

Alternative electrical conduction pathways (one fast and one slow) in the atrioventricular node (AV node) are the underlying cause of AVNRT. The presence of an extra, fast accessory pathway occasionally leads to a nonextinguishable circulating electrical impulse (reentrant circuit) within the AV node that activates the atria and ventricles simultaneously and at a rapid rate. This produces episodic symptoms of palpitations, dyspnea, chest pain, dizziness and/or syncope.

Key learning point: The most common cause of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is a reentrant circuit involving dual (fast and slow) pathways within the atrioventricular node.
Image Description:

AVNRT is a tachyarrhythmia caused by a dysfunctional AV node with two electrical pathways, one fast with a long refractory period and one slow with a short refractory period (dual AV nodal physiology). During normal sinus rhythm, the conduction occurs via the fast pathway, and the incoming current from the slow pathway is extinguished (top right image).

Typical AVNRT is triggered by an atrial premature beat (APB).

(1) An APB arrives at the AV node during the fast pathway's refractory period. The impulse is, therefore, conducted through the slow pathway, which is out of its refractory period.
(2) When the impulse reaches the distal junction of the two pathways, the fast pathway has recovered its excitability and the impulse can travel up retrograde.
(3) The impulse reaches the atria, leading to an almost simultaneous depolarization of the atria and ventricles. The current reenters the slow pathway.
(4) A reentry circuit is created with anterograde conduction across the slow-conducting pathway and retrograde conduction in the fast pathway resulting in sustained tachycardia.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms together with her ECG findings (narrow QRS complex with no discernible P waves) suggest paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT), which is most commonly caused by atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT).

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to your clinic to discuss the results of an electrocardiogram (ECG) that was performed during a pre-participation physical examination before joining her school’s soccer team. She is concerned about the ECG findings. She reports feeling well and has no chest pain, dyspnea, lightheadedness, or palpitations. She has a history of hypothyroidism, managed with levothyroxine 100 μg daily. Vital signs are normal. Cardiac auscultation reveals normal heart sounds without murmurs. Laboratory testing shows a normal complete blood count, and her thyroid-stimulating hormone and free thyroxine levels are within normal limits. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in response to her ECG findings?

choices.text: Increase the dose of the levothyroxine.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A variable R-R interval can be caused by a number of conditions (atrial fibrillation or flutter, atrial tachycardia, premature atrial contractions, and premature ventricular contractions), many of which are managed, at least in part, with a beta-blocker. However, patients with these conditions would have characteristic changes on their ECGs, such as absent or abnormal P-wave morphology, which is not the case for this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has a normal thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level; thus, the dose of levothyroxine seems appropriate, and no dose adjustment is indicated. Overreplacement with levothyroxine or other causes of thyrotoxicosis (which would cause a low TSH level) can lead to supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and other atrial arrhythmias, most commonly atrial fibrillation. In contrast, under-replacement with levothyroxine or untreated hypothyroidism (which would be associated with an elevated TSH level) can cause bradyarrhythmias.

C) INCORRECT:

An echocardiography is generally beneficial in the workup of SVT and other cardiac arrhythmias, to evaluate for potential etiologies such as valvular or structural heart disease. This patient, who has a normal sinus variant and no evidence of a pathologic arrhythmia, does not have any indication for additional imaging.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s electrocardiography (ECG) shows sinus rhythm with sinus arrhythmia, which is characterized by variations in the R-R interval (and thus the heart rate) with respiration (faster heart rate with inspiration and slower heart rate with expiration) and by normal, stable P-wave morphology. Sinus arrhythmia is due to variations in autonomic function with respiration. It is a benign, common finding in young, healthy patients and requires no intervention.

Key learning point: Benign sinus arrhythmia is a normal occurrence that does not require further treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

A 48-hour continuous ambulatory electrocardiographic monitor would be useful in a patient with cardiac symptoms occurring daily or near-daily, but it is not needed in this patient who is asymptomatic and has a resting ECG showing a benign normal variant.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with palpitations that began abruptly 45 minutes ago. He has a history of previous myocardial infarction. Vital signs are P, 165; BP 118/75. Physical examination reveals variable intensity of S1 heart sounds and intermittent cannon waves in the jugular venous pulse. ECG is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Supraventricular tachycardia with bundle branch block
Atrioventricular nodal reentry tachycardia with aberrancy
Atrial flutter with variable atrioventricular conduction

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient's ECG findings show regular wide-complex tachycardia, left axis deviation, QRS duration of 155 ms, and atrioventricular dissociation, which are all consistent with monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. The patient also risk factors that support the diagnosis, including age ≥ 50 years and structural heart disease (previous myocardial infarction), and physical findings of cannon waves and variable S1. Atrioventricular dissociation has a positive predictive value of 100% for ventricular tachycardia.

See also “VT vs. SVT with aberrancy.”

B) INCORRECT:

The regular rhythm and uniform QRS morphology shown on this patient's ECG are not consistent with polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia manifests with wide QRS complexes of variable morphology and usually has an irregular rhythm, not the regular wide-complex pattern seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

The presence of atrioventricular dissociation in this patient's ECG excludes supraventricular tachycardia with aberrant conduction. In SVT with bundle branch block, P waves precede all QRS complexes, and there is no atrioventricular dissociation. This patient's physical findings of cannon waves and variable S1 intensity further confirm the presence of AV dissociation.

D) INCORRECT:

The wide QRS complexes, left axis deviation, and atrioventricular dissociation in this patient's ECG are all inconsistent with atrioventricular nodal reentry tachycardia. This condition typically manifests with narrow QRS complexes that are accompanied or followed by P waves, but there is no atrioventricular dissociation.

E) INCORRECT:

The presence of atrioventricular dissociation in this patient's ECG excludes atrial flutter as the underlying rhythm. Atrial flutter typically manifests with a regular rhythm with sawtooth P waves and maintains an atrioventricular relationship rather than dissociation. Wide QRS complexes and left axis deviation are also atypical in atrial flutter.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department with dizziness and near syncope that began 2 hours ago. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 40; oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. The ECG is shown. The patient denies chest pain, shortness of breath, and palpitations. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Observation alone is inappropriate for a symptomatic patient with a Mobitz type II AV block who presents with a ventricular rate of ∼ 40/min and bifascicular block. Intermittent nonconducted P waves with varying AV conduction ratios (3:2, then 2:1) indicate unstable conduction that can suddenly progress to complete heart block, requiring immediate intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Isoproterenol is unlikely to be effective in treating Mobitz type II AV block with bifascicular block (RBBB with left anterior fascicular block). This type of block occurs below the AV node in the His-Purkinje system and does not respond to beta-adrenergic stimulation. Additionally, isoproterenol may increase myocardial oxygen demand and worsen ischemia.

C) INCORRECT:

While cardiology consultation is necessary for permanent pacemaker placement, the immediate priority is stabilizing this patient because he has symptoms and a ventricular rate of ∼ 40/min. His ECG shows an unstable Mobitz type II block with varying conduction ratios, requiring emergency intervention before consultation.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's ECG shows intermittent nonconducted P waves with constant PR intervals (∼ 240 ms) in conducted beats, confirming a Mobitz type II AV block. The presence of bifascicular block (RBBB with left anterior fascicular block) indicates infranodal pathology in the His-Purkinje system. Atropine is ineffective for this type of AV block because the conduction disturbance occurs below the AV node and does not respond to vagal blockade. Atropine may paradoxically worsen the block by increasing the atrial rate without improving infranodal conduction.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has a symptomatic Mobitz type II AV block with bifascicular block (RBBB with left anterior fascicular block) and a ventricular rate of ∼ 40/min. His ECG shows intermittent nonconducted P waves with varying AV conduction ratios, indicating unstable infranodal conduction. Transcutaneous pacing is the appropriate emergency intervention for treating symptomatic bradycardia in this patient, as this rhythm can suddenly progress to complete heart block.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient with a history of coronary artery disease presents with sudden-onset palpitations that began 20 minutes ago. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 170; R, 18; oxygen saturation, 96% on room air. The patient is alert and oriented. ECG is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The ECG shows a regular wide-complex tachycardia (QRS > 120 ms) at a rate of ∼ 170 bpm with uniform QRS morphology and absent P waves in a patient with coronary artery disease. These findings are consistent with monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. Adenosine is the first-line treatment for stable supraventricular tachycardia with narrow QRS complexes. However, adenosine is not effective for ventricular tachycardia because it acts on the atrioventricular node, which is not involved in ventricular arrhythmias.

B) INCORRECT:

The ECG shows regular wide-complex tachycardia with uniform QRS morphology consistent with monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. While electrical cardioversion is the preferred first-line approach in patients with structural heart disease, synchronized cardioversion at 100 J is preferred over defibrillation for monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. Defibrillation (unsynchronized cardioversion) at higher energy levels (120–200 J) is reserved for polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, pulseless ventricular tachycardia, or for when the device does not synchronize with the patient's rhythm. The synchronized approach reduces the risk of inducing ventricular fibrillation by timing the shock with the R-wave, making it safer and more appropriate for this patient with a stable, monomorphic rhythm.

C) INCORRECT:

The ECG findings of regular wide-complex tachycardia (QRS > 120 ms) at ∼170 bpm with uniform morphology and absent P waves are consistent with monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. While procainamide is generally the first-line antiarrhythmic medication for stable monomorphic ventricular tachycardia in patients without structural heart disease, electrical cardioversion is the first-line therapy in patients with structural heart disease such as coronary artery disease (CAD). Patients with CAD and ventricular arrhythmias are at higher risk for deterioration to sustained ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation, making rapid electrical conversion preferred over pharmacological cardioversion.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- The ECG findings of regular wide-complex tachycardia at ∼ 170 bpm with uniform QRS morphology and absent P waves are consistent with monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. In patients with structural heart disease (e.g., coronary artery disease), electrical cardioversion is preferred as the first-line therapy even in hemodynamically stable patients, because patients with ventricular arrhythmias due to structural heart disease are at increased risk of developing sustained ventricular tachycardia or ventricular fibrillation. Synchronized electrical cardioversion at 100 J is the appropriate initial dose for stable monomorphic ventricular tachycardia, providing rapid rhythm conversion while minimizing the risk of deterioration in this high-risk patient population.

E) INCORRECT:

The ECG findings of regular wide-complex tachycardia at ∼ 170 bpm with uniform QRS morphology and absent P waves are consistent with monomorphic ventricular tachycardia. Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker used for supraventricular tachycardia. Verapamil should be avoided in this patient because it can worsen ventricular tachycardia by reducing contractility and blood pressure.
